org.funcito

Class FuncitoJedi

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.funcito.FuncitoJedi

  • public class FuncitoJedi
extends Object
    This class is the static entry point of the Funcito API for Jedi.

    • Method Detail

      • callsTo

        public static <T> T callsTo(Class<T> clazz)
        Generates a proxy object for use with other FuncitoJedi static methods. This proxy should not be used for any other purposes. It is a convenience pass-thru to FuncitoDelegate.callsTo(Class). Example usages are: 

         
     // inlined:
     Functor<MyClass,RetType1> func = functorFor( callsTo(MyClass.class).methodWithRetType1() );

     // or extracted for repeat usage
     final MyClass CALLS_TO = callsTo(MyClass.class);
     Functor<MyClass,RetType1> func2 = functorFor( CALLS_TO.method1WithRetType1() );
     Functor<MyClass,RetType2> func3 = functorFor( CALLS_TO.method2WithRetType2() );

        Stubs are cached, so this method can be called multiple times for the same class without penalty. But a single proxy can also be reused for creating multiple Jedi Functor or Filter objects.

        Parameters:
        clazz - is the class to be proxied
        Returns:
        a proxy which can be used by other FuncitoJedi static methods

      • functorFor

        public static <T,V> Functor<T,V> functorFor(V proxiedMethodCall)
        Generates a Jedi Functor object that wraps a method call or method chain. Resulting Functor is as thread-safe as the method itself. Example usage is:

        Functor<MyClass,RetType1> func = functorFor( callsTo(MyClass.class).methodWithRetType1() );

        You can wrap methods with parameters, so long as you statically provide values for each parameter. Provided parameter values are statically bound to the Function and may not be changed:

        Functor<MyClass,RetType1> func = functorFor( callsTo(MyClass.class).methodWithArgs("abc", 123L) );
        // all invocations of func will use "abc" and 123L as the arguments to methodWithArgs

        It is also possible to wrap method call chains, with some restrictions:

        MyClass callMyClass = callsTo(MyClass.class);
        Functor<MyClass,RetType2> func = functorFor( callMyClass.methodWithRetType1().methodWithRetType2() );

        Restrictions for chaining are that intermediate return types (all except for the final return type in the chain) must be proxyable by the current Proxy provider, just like the initial target type. In the above example this means MyClass and RetType1 must be proxyable, but RetType2 need not be proxyable. Intermediate return types also cannot be a Java Generic type because of type erasure.

        Parameters:
        proxiedMethodCall - is the return value from a method call to a FuncitoJedi proxy object
        Returns:
        a Jedi Functor object that wraps the method call or chain.

      • functorFor

      • filterFor

        public static <T> Filter<T> filterFor(Boolean proxiedMethodCall)
        Generates a Jedi Filter object that wraps a Boolean- or boolean-return method call or method chain. Resulting Filter is as thread-safe as the method itself. Auto-boxing means you may always safely wrap a method that has a primitive boolean return type. Example usage is:

        Filter<MyClass> filter = filterFor( callsTo(MyClass.class).methodWithBoolRetType() );

        Methods returning either boolean primitive or Boolean wrapper objects may be wrapped without problems.

        This method also supports wrapping methods with arguments, and method chaining, as documented in functorFor(Object).

        Parameters:
        proxiedMethodCall - is the Boolean return value from a method call to a FuncitoJedi proxy object
        Returns:
        a Jedi Filter object that wraps the method call or method chain.

      • filterFor

      • commandFor

        public static <T> Command<T> commandFor(Object proxiedMethodCall)
        Generates a Jedi Command object that wraps a method call or method chain. Resulting Command is as thread-safe as the method/chain itself. This Command generator can only be used for method calls/chains with a non-void return type, even though the return type is ignored. For a Command generator that works with void returning methods/chains, see voidCommand(). Example usage is:

        Command<MyClass> cmd = commandFor( callsTo(MyClass.class).methodWithNonVoidReturnType() );

        You can wrap methods with parameters, so long as you statically provide values for each parameter. Provided parameter values are statically bound to the Command and may not be changed:

        Command<MyClass> cmd = commandFor( callsTo(MyClass.class).methodWithArgs("abc", 123L) );
        // all invocations of command will use "abc" and 123L as the arguments to methodWithArgs

        It is also possible to wrap method call chains, with some restrictions:

        MyClass callMyClass = callsTo(MyClass.class);
        Command<MyClass> cmd = commandFor( callsMyClass.methodWithRetType1().methodWithRetType2() );

        Restrictions for chaining are that intermediate return types (all except for the final return type in the chain) must be proxyable by the current Proxy provider, just like the initial target type. In the above example this means MyClass and RetType1 must be proxyable, but RetType2 need not be proxyable. Intermediate return types also cannot be a Java Generic type because of type erasure.

        Type Parameters:
        T - is the input type of the Command
        Parameters:
        proxiedMethodCall - is the return value from an inlined method call to a FuncitoFJ proxy object
        Returns:
        a Jedi Command object that wraps a method call or chain.
        See Also:
        voidCommand()

      • commandFor

        public static <T> Command<T> commandFor(Object proxiedMethodCall,
                        TypedMode<Void> mode)

        Returns:
        a Jedi Command object that wraps the method call or chain.
        See Also:
        commandFor(Object), Modes, TypedMode

      • prepareVoid

        public static <T> T prepareVoid(T t)
        Prepares a method-call or method-chain call that terminates with a void return type, for generation of a Jedi Command object. Use of this method must be followed with execution of one of the void-Command methods: voidCommand(), voidCommand(TypedMode), voidCommand(Mode). Resulting Command is as thread-safe as the method/chain itself. Example usage is:

        prepareVoid(callsTo(MyClass.class)).methodWithVoidReturnType();

        You can wrap methods with parameters, so long as you statically provide values for each parameter. Provided parameter values are statically bound to the Command and may not be changed:

        prepareVoid(callsTo(MyClass.class)).voidMethodWithArgs("abc", 123L);
        // all invocations of command will use "abc" and 123L as the arguments to voidMethodWithArgs

        It is also possible to wrap method call chains, with some restrictions:

        MyClass callMyClass = callsTo(MyClass.class);
        prepareVoid(callsMyClass).methodWithRetType1().voidMethod();

        Restrictions for chaining are that intermediate return types (final return type does not matter because it is void) must be proxyable by the current Proxy provider, just like the initial target type. In the above example this means MyClass and RetType1 must be proxyable. Intermediate return types also cannot be a Java Generic type because of type erasure.

        Type Parameters:
        T - is the input type of the Command being prepared
        Returns:
        the same Funcito proxy object that is passed in. Provided for fluent API so that desired method chain call may be directly appended.
        See Also:
        voidCommand()

      • voidCommand

        public static <T> Command<T> voidCommand()
        Generates a Jedi Command object that wraps a method call or method chain. Resulting Command is as thread-safe as the method/chain itself. This Command generator is only appropriate for method calls/chains with a void return type, and it requires previous usage of prepareVoid(Object). Example usage is:

        prepareVoid(callsTo(MyClass.class)).methodWithVoidReturnType();
        Command<MyClass> cmd = voidCommand();

        Type Parameters:
        T - is the input type of the Command
        Returns:
        a Jedi Command object that wraps a previously prepared method call or chain.
        See Also:
        prepareVoid(Object)

      • voidCommand

        public static <T> Command<T> voidCommand(TypedMode<Void> mode)

        Parameters:

        voidCommand(), Modes, TypedMode
